0.53 0.17 Catalytic hydrogenolysis of lignin with NiO-CuO catalyst via alcohol-water coprecipitation Fengkai Liang Writing – original draft Data curation Validation Yanbo Yin Writing – original draft Data curation Tiantian Jiao Writing – review & editing Xiangping Li Writing – review & editing Haifeng Zhou Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology Project administration ⁎ Peng Liang Writing – review & editing ⁎ Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Energy and Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Shandong University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266590, China Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Energy and Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Shandong University of Science and Technology Qingdao 266590 China Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Energy and Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Shandong University of Science and Technology, Qingdao, 266590, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Using lignin to produce valuable chemicals can help reduce reliance on fossil fuels. The NiO catalyst prepared by alcohol/water co-precipitation method showed higher activity than NiO prepared by ammonia-water precipitation method in catalytic hydrogenolysis (CH) reaction of enzymatic hydrolysis lignin (EHL). The yield of lignin oil reached 85.68 % at 270 °C for 30 min. The catalytic performance was further improved by the introduction of CuO. Under the optimized conditions (290 °C, 120 min), the yield of lignin oil was up to 95.13 % using N-C (4:1) as the catalyst. The GC-MS analysis showed that the lignin oil mainly consisted of phenols, esters, hydrocarbons, and other oxygenated compounds, among which, the phenolic content was up to 57.90 %. These results indicate that the prepared catalyst can effectively break the C-O and C-C bonds in lignin and significantly promote the formation of phenolics. Graphical Abstract Keywords Lignin Catalytic hydrogenolysis Bimetal catalyst Phenolic compounds Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With escalating fossil fuel depletion and attendant environmental pollution, there is a pressing requirement for renewable energy alternatives, such as solar, wind, and bioenergy [1]. Biomass is widely sought after because of its abundant reserves and low price. Lignin constitutes 10–30 % of overall lignocellulosic biomass, yet proving up to 40 % of the energy content [2]. As the predominant aromatic biopolymer found abundantly in nature, lignin possesses substantial potential for conversion into various high-value bioproducts, notably aromatic chemicals [3]. Nonetheless, its inherent stability renders lignin recalcitrant to depolymerization processes. Enzymatic hydrolysis lignin (EHL), a byproduct from the conversion of lignocellulosic to ethanol. According to statistics, about 1 ton of waste is generated for every 1 ton of fuel ethanol produced, which contains 40–50 % of lignin [4]. As the national advances in harnessing renewable resources, EHL emerges as an abundant and renewable feedstock. Comprehensive application of EHL can substantially decrease the production costs associated with lignocellulosic ethanol, thereby bolstering the competitiveness of the biofuels industry [5]. However, at the present phase, EHL has not been effectively developed and utilized. A large amount of EHL is simply burned as fuel, which causes a huge waste of resources [6]. There are a variety of methods for depolymerizing lignin into high value-added chemicals, including gasification [7], pyrolysis [8], catalytic oxidation [9], biocatalysis [10] and catalytic hydrogenolysis [11]. Among various methods, catalytic hydrogenolysis (CH) is favored for its many advantages, which include high conversion rates, low carbon accumulation and high product selectivity. It is therefore considered as a highly efficient approach for lignin depolymerization [12]. For example, Tianjin Li et al. [13] prepared Ru@N-doped carbon catalysts by two-stage pyrolysis using melamine as a soft template, with a maximum aromatic monomer yield of 30.5 % at 300 °C. Zhaolin Dou et al. [14] used TiO2 as a carrier to prepare Pd-PdO/TiO2 catalysts for the self-hydrogen transfer hydrogenolysis (STH) of native lignin, loaded with using Pd as the dehydrogenation site and PdO to activate the Cβ-O bond, which effectively promoted the breakage of the β-O-4 bond, and the yield of the resulting lignin monomers was 40 wt% at 180 °C. Although the catalytic activity of precious metals is high and the reaction temperature is low. Its cost, however, limits large-scale applications. Ni-based catalysts are a widely used product due to their good catalytic hydrogenation capabilities and relatively low price [15]. Weijie Zhao et al. [16] used a Ni/MgO catalyst to achieve CH of lignin to produce the multifunctional petroleum-based monophenols with a yield of 15 %, of which 42 % was a widely used fine chemical (4-ethyl phenol). To improve the selectivity and catalytic activity of a single nickel metal, the addition of another metal to form a bimetallic synergy has been widely used for lignin depolymerization [17]. It is reported that Ni-Cu bimetallic catalysts have been used for the hydrodeoxygenation of biomass-derived carbonyl compounds [18]. Ni-Cu bimetals exhibit better catalytic activity compared to monometallic Ni and Cu. Up to 89.5 % cyclopentanone was achieved for the aqueous phase hydrogenation of furfural. The above mentioned indicates that synergistic effects between Ni-Cu atoms, namely electronic and structural effects, have a significant impact on enhancing their performance. At this stage, supported catalysts are more widely studied [19–21]. Nevertheless, the synthesis process of supported catalysts is more complicated, meanwhile, the catalytic activity is strongly influenced by the content of the active component. In contrast, unsupported catalysts consist mainly of active metal components without a carrier. In addition, the unit mass of the active component is higher compared to the supported catalyst [22]. Unsupported catalysts can also tailor their catalytic activity in a variety of ways by adjusting particle size and morphology [23]. Wenjing Song et al. [24] prepared a Co-doped MoS2 for the hydrodeoxygenation of five lignin-derived phenols with yields of more than 85 % of the corresponding aromatics (benzene, toluene and xylene). However, current research on unsupported catalysts has mainly focused on transition metal sulphides and on metal ontology catalysts [25,26]. Little research has been reported on metal oxide catalysts [27]. Common methods for the synthesis of metal nanoparticles include sol-gel [28], hydrothermal [29], thermal decomposition [30] and co-precipitation methods [31]. The co-precipitation method is preferred for its simplicity, low cost and adjustable reaction conditions. S. Thambidurai et al. [32] applied a facile co-precipitation method to synthesize basic ZnO nanoparticles and NiO-ZnO nanocomposites with particle sizes ranged from 25 to 200 nm. During the precipitation process, the introduction of substances with low dielectric constants to the aqueous solution can change the thermodynamics and nucleation kinetics of the reaction process, resulting in smaller sized nanoparticles [33]. Hu et al. [34] used a mixed alcohol/water solution as a medium to prepare ZrO2 powder. The dielectric properties of the mixed alcohol/water solution were found to directly affect the nucleation and growth of zirconia particles in the solution. Li Yue et al. [35] synthesized a series of CoMoO4 using various alcohol/water solvent systems and obtained the corresponding sulfides by calcination vulcanization. It revealed that the variation of the solvent system could effectively regulate the particle size of the precursors. Herein, we prepared a series of NiO, CuO and NiO-CuO catalysts by precipitation and alcohol/water co-precipitation methods. The catalysts were characterized using XRD, SEM, TEM, XPS, BET and others. The performance of the catalysts was evaluated by the CH of EHL. The GC-MS characterization was employed to investigate the composition of the lignin oil. In addition, the effect of operating conditions on the product was discussed and possible reaction pathways were explored. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All materials were described in supplementary material. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts Nickel oxide was prepared by ammonia precipitation method. Specifically, a 5 wt% solution of NH3·H2O was added dropwise to 210 mL of distilled water containing 3.8 g of NiCl2·6 H2O. The pH of the solution was adjusted to 9.5. Then, the mixture was agitated at a constant speed for 240 min. After filtration, the resulting powder was dried at 80 °C for 12 h. The powder was then calcined at 400 °C for 1 h. The catalyst was named as NiO (N). NiO-CuO catalysts were synthesized by an alcohol-water co-precipitation method. Different molar ratios (1:1, 4:1 and 9:1) of Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O and Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O were dissolved in 150 mL of deionized water and stirred for 30 min. An amount of NH4HCO3 (The molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to (Ni2++Cu2+) is 2:1) and 100 mL of anhydrous ethanol were added and stirred at 60 °C for 30 minutes. After filtration, the powder was dried in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h and then kept in a muffle furnace at 250 °C for 1 h at 1 °C /min. The catalysts obtained were recorded as N-C (1:1), N-C (4:1) and N-C (9:1). Pure NiO and CuO were prepared in a similar way, except that only the corresponding nitrate was added during the preparation, recorded as NiO (A) and CuO (A), respectively. 2.3 Catalytic hydrogenolysis (CH) of enzymatic hydrolysis lignin (EHL) EHL was purified using sulfuric acid precipitation method. A certain amount of EHL, catalyst and ethanol was added in a stainless-steel autoclave for the reaction. After the reaction, the solid residue and lignin oil were analyzed and weighed. The details were described in the supplementary material. 2.4 Characterization The details of various characterization for catalyst and lignin oil composition were described in supplementary material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The XRD patterns of the prepared catalysts are displayed in Fig. 1. The peaks of NiO (N) and CuO (A) are consistent with their respective standard cards (NiO: JCPDS 47–1049, CuO: JCPDS 89–5898). The intensity of the XRD peaks is high, indicating a high degree of crystallinity of the samples. In contrast, the XRD of NiO (A) shows a different situation with lower peak intensity and wider half-peak width. The lower calcination temperature (250 °C) may lead to a less crystalline sample [36]. The broadening of the peaks suggests the small size of the NiO particles [37]. Comparing different N-C catalysts, the intensity of the NiO peaks is found to decrease gradually with increasing CuO content, and at 1:1 even only the peak of CuO appears. This is because the ionic radii of the Cu2+ and Ni2+ are close to each other, and the Cu2+ replace some of the Ni2+ in the NiO lattice, reducing the crystallinity of NiO and leading to a decrease in peak intensity [38,39]. After calcination at 250 °C, the crystallinity of CuO is higher, so only the peaks of CuO appear for N-C (1:1). To obtain the microscopic morphology of the catalysts, SEM analysis was performed. Different preparation methods affect the microstructure of the catalysts. NiO (N) in Fig. 2a shows an aggregated lamellar structure. CuO (A) (Fig. 2b) is a lyotropic microsphere structure with an average particle size of 230.2 nm, which is composed of many small particles. For NiO (A) in Fig. 2c, it exhibits a particle size of about 101.3 nm, composed of more regular spherical particles. After CuO doping, the morphology of the sample is very similar to that of NiO (A), but there is a significant reduction in particle size. The size of N-C (9:1) is about 83.5 nm (Fig. 2d); the size of N-C (4:1) is reduced to 70.8 nm and the agglomeration is more pronounced (Fig. 2e). In contrast, the N-C (1:1) of Fig. 2f becomes a more regular spherical structure with a reduced average particle size of 62.5 nm. The reduction in particle size results from the influence of dopants on the sample size through their participation in growth and nucleation processes, which is intricately connected to the concentration of Cu2+ [40,41]. This phenomenon can be associated with the ‘Zener pinning effect’, where the force driving the outward movement of grain boundaries is counteracted by the force generated due to defects within the crystal structure [42]. Consequently, the metal ion doping concentration is crucial for the size regulation of NiO nanoparticles [43]. Moreover, elemental mapping (Fig. 2k) confirms the homogeneous distribution of Ni, Cu, and O elements within N-C (4:1), indicative of successful catalyst synthesis. The nanoscale architecture of N-C (4:1) was further investigated via TEM. As shown in Fig. 2 (g-h), the sample is made up of quasi-spherical particles aggregated, which coincides with the SEM images. A High Resolution TEM (HR-TEM) analysis was conducted to study the lattice fringes of the sample. The interplanar spacings of 0.252 nm is indicative of the (111) plane of NiO, while the 0.234 nm spacing corresponds to the (111) plane of CuO. The surface characteristics and chemical composition of N-C (4:1) were probed using XPS, revealing the presence of Cu, Ni, O and C elements. The XPS spectrum of Cu 2p exhibited two principal peaks at 934.4 eV and 954.6 eV, which are ascribed to the Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2, respectively. Additionally, the presence of CuO is further confirmed by the two satellite peaks observed at 961.9 eV and 941.6 eV [44]. The Ni 2p XPS spectrum exhibits two peaks at 855.1 eV and 872.9 eV, characteristic of Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2, respectively. The presence of satellite peaks at 861 eV and 879.14 eV further confirms the presence of Ni in its oxidized state [45]. Additionally, the O 1 s spectrum is deconvoluted, revealing peaks at 529.7 eV and 531.4 eV, corresponding to metal oxygen bonds (Ni/Cu-O) and adsorbed oxygen on the surface, respectively [46,47]. The N2 adsorption-desorption curves of various catalysts are depicted in Fig. 4. In accordance with IUPAC classification, it is evident, with the exception of the NiO (N), are categorized under type IV isotherms, signifying mesoporous materials. The NiO (N) sample, however, aligns with type III isotherms, suggesting a weaker interaction with N2 and a less pronounced presence of various pores, which is corroborated by SEM observations. All catalysts exhibit H3-type hysteresis loops, indicative of mesoporous structures. As depicted in Table S1, the catalysts predominantly exhibit microporous and mesoporous characteristics; however, the proportion of mesopores increases progressively with the introduction of CuO. The SBET of NiO (N) is only 30.4 m2/g, the Dp is 6.68 nm, and the Vtot is only 0.01 cm3/g. However, the SBET of NiO (A) is as high as 150.5 m2/g and the Vtot is 0.05 cm3/g, but the Dp decreases to 2.63 nm. The SBET, Vtot and Dp of the catalyst increases with increasing CuO incorporation. The SBET of N-C (9:1) is 167.1 m2/g, the Vtot is 0.06 cm3/g, and the Dp increases slightly to 3.68 nm. While the SBET of N-C (4:1) and N-C (1:1) increases to 185.5 m2/g and 200.7 m2/g, respectively. The Vtot also increases to 0.08 cm3/g and 0.11 cm3/g, and the Dp increases to 5.37 nm and 6.48 nm, respectively. In addition, the data of CuO (A) are also presented in the table. It can be seen that CuO (A) has a low SBET of 100.9 m2/g. The Vtot is 0.03 cm3/g, but CuO (A) has the largest Dp of 8.15 nm. To delve deeper into the influence of copper doping on the catalyst, NH3-TPD analyses were conducted. The corresponding profiles are presented in Fig. 5. The NH3 desorption peaks with varying intensities at different temperatures intervals signify the presence of different acidic sites. Consequently, the NH3 desorption peaks within the temperature ranges 30–200 °C, 200–400 °C and above 400 °C in Fig. 5 are classified as weak, medium and strong acid sites, respectively [48]. Both samples have broad desorption peaks. It suggests a wide range of acid intensity distribution in the catalysts. However, the peak area increases with the incorporation of CuO, signifying an escalation in the acid strength of N-C (4:1). This enhancement is attributed to the Cu ions potentially substituting for protons in the Bronsted acid sites, thereby augmenting the overall acidity of the catalysts. Table S2 delineates the concentration of acidic sites within the catalysts. The total acid amount of NiO (A) is 0.68 mmol/g compared to 1.03 mmol/g for N-C (4:1). There is a significant increase in mid-acid strength after doping with CuO (0.26 mmol/g vs. 0.45 mmol/g). The acidity of catalysts is a critical parameter influencing the conversion and selectivity of lignin, which is a key factor contributing to the enhanced conversion efficiency observed with the N-C (4:1) catalyst [49]. For N-C (4:1), a low-temperature shift in the NH3-TPD desorption peak is observed, primarily due to the modification of surface acidic site characteristics induced by CuO. Specifically, the presence of CuO can regulate the electronic structure of NiO, thereby affecting the distribution and acidity of surface acidic sites. Additionally, the synergy between CuO and NiO leads to the formation of bimetallic active sites, which enhances the adsorptive capacity for NH3 and diminishes the energy threshold for NH3 desorption. Consequently, NH3 molecules desorb at lower temperatures, resulting in the observed low-temperature shift of the NH3-TPD desorption peak. 3.2 Effect of different catalysts on the CH of EHL The CH behavior of various catalysts for EHL degradation was assessed under precise reaction parameters. As delineated in Fig. 6, only 48.01 % of the lignin oil is obtained when no catalyst is added, while the solid residue yield is 50.37 %. modestly elevates the lignin oil yield to 60.04 %, suggesting that the NiO (N) possesses low CH efficiency for lignin degradation. However, when NiO (A) prepared by alcohol-water co-precipitation is used, the lignin oil of yield is markedly enhanced to 85.68 %, with a corresponding decrement in solid residue to 12.17 %. The CH efficiency of NiO (A) is superior to that of NiO (N), likely due to its enhanced specific surface area and reduced particle size, which are known to influence catalytic activity. Furthermore, the lignin oil yield is influenced by the incorporation of CuO. The yield of lignin oil first increases and then decreases with the increment of CuO doping, reaching a peak of 92.11 % for N-C (4:1). To explore the main active component of the catalyst, we prepared CuO (A) by the alcohol/water method as a comparison. The observed yield of lignin oil (55.16 %) implies that the predominant catalytic component in N-C (4:1) is NiO, CuO is primainly employed as a supplementary agent to enhance the overall catalytic activity. Therefore, we used N-C (4:1) catalysts in all subsequent experiments. 3.3 Effect of reaction conditions on CH of EHL 3.3.1 Reaction temperature As illustrated in Fig. 7, when the temperature is 210 °C and 230 °C, the yield of lignin oil is only 55.65 % and 57.56 %, while more solid residue is produced (43.35 % and 40.17 %). This indicates that the lower activity of N-C (4:1) at the reaction temperatures of 210 °C and 230 °C leads to inadequate CH of EHL. After elevating the temperature to 250 °C, the lignin oil yield rapidly rises to 77.37 %, with the corresponding solid residue yield diminishing to 21.58 %. This trend culminates at 290 °C, where the lignin oil yield peaks at 92.37 %, and the solid residue yield is only 6.15 %. However, With further increasing the temperature to 310 °C, the lignin oil yield retreats to 87.13 % and the solid residue yield ascends to 11.52 %. These observations intimate the presence of competing reactions during the CH of EHL, with one pathway being the hydrogenolysis of EHL and the other being the repolymerization of the reaction products. When the temperature is below 290 °C, lignin hydrogenolysis produces oligomers, and the CH reaction takes the initiative at this time. When the temperature surpasses 290 °C, oligomers, rich in unsaturated bonds, undergo intermolecular repolymerization, consequently boosting the solid formation within the system. 3.3.2 Reaction time Fig. 8 shows the effect of reaction time (20–360 min) on the lignin oil and solid residue yields during CH at a reaction temperature of 290 °C. The yield of lignin oil is 92.01 % at a reaction time of 20 min. The solid residue yield is only 7.99 %. This indicates that N-C (4:1) has a high catalytic performance and is able to depolymerize EHL in a very short period of time. The yield of lignin oil experiences a marginal increase with the extension of reaction time, culminating at 95.13 % at 90 min, with the solid residue yield concurrently diminishing to 3.02 %. Upon further prolongation of the reaction time to 180 min, the lignin oil yield remains relatively constant, fluctuating within the bounds of experimental error. This indicates that CH has proceeded to the stage of complete conversion of EHL in the system. However, when the reaction time is extended to 360 min, the yield of lignin oil diminishes to 91.89 %. This downturn is potentially attributable to the concurrent side reactions of some products. The prolonged reaction duration may enhance the recombination of depolymerized lignin fragments. 3.3.3 Catalyst dosages As illustrated in Fig. 9, when no catalyst is added, the yield of lignin oil is only 55.06 % and more solid residue are formed. For the addition of 0.1 g of N-C (4:1), the lignin oil yield escalates to 70.25 %, with the solid residue yield diminishing to 29.75 %. With an increment in N-C (4:1) dosage from 0.1 g to 0.5 g, the lignin oil yield progressively ascends due to the proliferation of catalytic active sites, culminating at 95.13 % at a 0.5 g catalyst dosage. Concurrently, the solid residue yield retreats to 3.02 %. Further increasing the catalyst dosage, the lignin oil yield remains basically unchanged. 3.4 Product analysis To elucidate the impact of CuO on the catalytic performance and the reaction mechanism, NiO (A) and N-C (4:1) are selected as catalysts for the CH of EHL. Lignin oil produced at varying temperatures (210, 290 and 310 °C) and durations (20, 90 and 360 min) are subjected to GC-MS for detailed characterization. Based on the GC-MS spectra, these lignin oil components can be broadly classified into phenols, esters, hydrocarbons and other oxygenated compounds. Broadly speaking, phenolic compounds predominate in lignin oil. These phenols are further divided into Phenol-type (H-type) (4-Ethylphenol, 4-Isopropylphenol, 2-Ethylphenol and 3-Ethyl-5-methylphenol etc.), Guaiacol-type (G-type) (4-Ethyl-2-methoxyphenol and 2-Methoxy-4-propyl-phenol etc.) and Eugenol-type (S-type) (2,6-Dimethoxy-4-methylphenol and 2,6-Dimethoxyphenol etc.). The composition of lignin oil generated with the two catalysts is delineated in Table S3. When NiO (A) serves as the catalyst, phenols accounts for 57.25 %, and the percentages of G-type and H-type phenols are 28.24 % and 23.13 %, respectively. A minor concentration of S-type phenols is detected, constituting 4.95 % of the lignin oil. The phenolic monomers yield decreases to 53.24 % when N-C (4:1) is used as the catalyst. The proportion of G-type and H-type phenols is observed to diminish to 26.87 % and 21.09 %, respectively, while the S-type phenols' content remains relatively stable at 4.67 %. The three phenolic compounds with the highest contents are 4-ethyl-2-methoxy phenol, 4-ethylphenol and 2,6-dimethoxyphenol, and the percent peak areas of the above three phenols are 19.15 %, 23.21 % and 4.67 %, respectively. For other aromatic compounds, the percentage of esters and aromatics also varies depending on the catalyst. When NiO (A) is the catalyst, the percentage of esters in lignin oil is 18.00 % and the aromatic product is only 3.34 %. The percentage of esters and aromatics increases to 25.42 % and 9.67 % when N-C (4:1) is the catalyst. Among the esters, Ethyl 3-(4-hydroxy-3-Methoxyphenyl)propionate, Ethyl 4-Hydroxyhydrocinnamate and Dibutyl phthalate are identified as the predominant constituents, with respective concentrations of 15.67 %, 6.61 % and 2.71 %. The aromatic compounds are mainly 4-ethylbiphenyl and 4-propylbiphenyl with 6.50 % and 3.17 %, respectively. The formation of esters is often attributed to esterification reaction between ethanol and lignin-derived intermediates, which is significantly influenced by the acidity of the catalyst. These findings suggest that the augmentation of catalyst acidity through the introduction of CuO is more conducive to deoxygenation reactions, leading to a higher conversion of aromatics, and also promotes esterification reactions, which in turn results in increased proportion of ester products. The properties of lignin oil derived from reactions at varying temperatures using N-C (4:1) are listed. The results in Table S4. The components of lignin oil are dominated by phenols. When the reaction temperature is 210 °C, fewer components are detected, and the percentage of phenols is only 35.74 %. It mainly includes six kinds of phenols, mainly G-type and H-type phenols, and no S-type phenols are detected. At lower temperatures, the inefficiency of N-C (4:1) in cleaving C-O and C-C bonds within lignin leads to diminished yields of phenolic monomers. However, elevating the reaction temperature to 290 °C augments the phenolic product content to 56.72 %, with the number of species expanding to 11. The content of G-type and H-type phenols increases to 33.12 % and 17.96 %, respectively, while S-type phenols are also detected. 4-Ethyl-2-methoxyphenol, 4-Ethylphenol, 2-Methoxy-4-methylphenol, 2-Methoxy-4-propylphenol and 4-(3-Hydroxypropyl)-2,6-dimethoxyphenol have the highest contents with percentages of 21.17 %, 16.21 %, 3.87 %, 4.01 % and 2.93 %, respectively. The content of phenolic products decreases when the reaction temperature is further increase to 310 °C. This reduction in phenolic monomers content may stem from the condensation of lignin-derived monomers at elevated temperatures, which leads to a decrease in the availability of reactive phenolic monomers species. Other aromatic compounds are dominated by esters and aromatic hydrocarbons. Elevated temperature increases promote the prevalence of deoxygenation and condensation reactions, consequently increasing the proportionate content of these compounds. The percent peak areas of Dibutyl phthalate, Ethyl 4-Hydroxyhydrocinnamate, Ethyl 3-(4-hydroxy-3-methoxyphenyl) propionate, 4-Ethylbiphenyl and 4-Propylbiphenyl are 5.40 %, 6.91 %, 12.23 %, 4.95 % and 5.93 % at 310 °C, respectively. Furthermore, the influence of reaction duration on the production of monomers was ascertained. As listed in Table 1, when the reaction time is 20 min, the total phenolic content is 49.03 %, dominated by G-type and H-type phenols with 28.02 % and 20.01 %, respectively. The concentration of 4-Ethylphenol constitutes 15.17 %, whereas that of 4-Ethyl-2-methoxyphenol accounts for 16.40 % of the total lignin oil composition. The percentage of esters is 13.15 %, and no S-type phenols or hydrocarbon products are detected. When the reaction time is extended to 120 min, there are more identifiable monomer products and the content of phenolic products increases to 57.90 %, which indicates that a proper extension of the reaction time is beneficial to the depolymerization of lignin. The percentages of G-type and H-type phenols are 32.77 % and 22.41 %, respectively. The concentrations of 4-Ethylphenol and 4-Ethyl-2-methoxyphenol escalates to 18.01 % and 20.93 %, respectively, while the proportion of S-type phenols also exhibit an increment, reaching 5.01 %. Among esters, Dibutyl phthalate, Ethyl 3-(4-hydroxyphenyl)propanoate and Ethyl 3-(4-hydroxy-3-methoxyphenyl)propionate are the main products, with contents of 4.21 %, 7.48 % and 8.96 %, respectively. As the reaction time is further increased to 360 min, the phenolic monomers content decreases to 52.74 %. The content of 4-Ethylphenol and 4-Ethyl-2-methoxyphenol further decreases to 14.72 % and 15.85 %. However, the content of ester products increases to 28.85 %. In contrast, the aromatic products do not change much and only slightly increases to 7.84 %. The possible reason for this phenomenon is caused by the esterification and condensation reactions between the monomers of lignin oil with the excessive prolongation of the reaction time. 3.5 Possible depolymerization mechanisms Based on the principal products of lignin depolymerization, we have delineated the potential reaction pathway ( Fig. 10). Ferulic acid (1) and p-Coumaric acid (2), which are predominant structure units of EHL, can be liberated through the depolymerization of lignin [50]. These compounds can undergo esterification and subsequent hydrogenation, yielding ethyl 4-hydroxy-3-methoxy-phenylpropionate (4) and Ethyl 4-Hydroxyhydrocinnamate (7), respectively. They can also be decarboxylated to produce 2-Methoxy-4-vinylphenol (5) and 4-Hydrozystyrene (8) [51,52], then hydrogenated to produce 4-Ethyl-2-methoxyphenol (6) and 4-Ethylphenol (9), respectively. Coniferyl alcohol (3) can either be hydrogenated through the side chain to produce Homovanillyl alcohol (12) or dehydroxylated to produce Isoeugenol (10) [53]. Homovanillyl alcohol (12) can undergo a dehydroxymethylation reaction to produce 4-Ethyl-2-methoxyphenol (6) or a dehydration reaction to produce Eugenol (13), and the same product, 2-Methoxy-5-propyl-phenol (11), is obtained by hydrogenation of Isoeugenol (10) and Eugenol (13). The decomposition of the aryl group of Eugenol (13) gives 2-Methoxy-4-methylphenol (14) [54]. Dihydro cuminyl alcohol (3) undergoes hydrogenation to form Dihydrosinapyl alcohol (15), as indicated by the reference [55], which subsequently experiences a dehydration reaction to form Elemicin (16). The allylic decomposition of Elemicin (16) results in the formation of 3,5-Dimethoxy-4-hydroxytoluene (17) [56], which then undergoes a demethylation reaction to produce 2,6-Dimethoxyphenol (18). In addition, Dibutyl phthalate (24) is also present among the products. It is documented that Ethanol (19) can undergo dehydrogenation in the presence of a catalyst, leading to the formation of Acetaldehyde (20) [57,58]. The hydrogen radicals can be involved in the hydrogenolysis of lignin, and acetaldehyde can then undergo a series of reactions to produce 1-Butanol (22) [59]. Therefore, Diethyl phthalate (24) may be formed by the esterification of Phthalic acid (23) produced during EHL depolymerization with 1-Butanol (22). 4 Conclusions A series of NiO (NiO (A)), CuO (CuO (A)) and various bimetallic mixed oxide catalysts (N-C (9:1), N-C (4:1) and N-C (1:1)) were synthesized using the alcohol/water co-precipitation method. NiO (NiO (N)) prepared via the ammonia precipitation method served as a comparison. Compared to NiO (N), NiO (A) exhibited higher catalytic activity with 85.68 % of lignin oil produced. The introduction of CuO further enhanced the depolymerization of EHL, which might be due to the larger specific surface area and increased total acidity. Among all lignin oil samples, the content of phenolic products was dominant. Under the optimized experimental conditions, using N-C (4:1) as a catalyst, the yield of phenolic monomers in lignin oil reached 57.90 %, with the highest relative contents of 4-ethylphenol and 4-ethyl-2-methoxyphenol being 18.01 % and 20.93 %, respectively. Furthermore, this study explored the potential mechanism of lignin depolymerization catalyzed by N-C (4:1). This work offers a cost-effective and highly efficient strategy for the selective depolymerization of lignin. coredata.dc:description: Using lignin to produce valuable chemicals can help reduce reliance on fossil fuels. The NiO catalyst prepared by alcohol/water co-precipitation method showed higher activity than NiO prepared by ammonia-water precipitation method in catalytic hydrogenolysis (CH) reaction of enzymatic hydrolysis lignin (EHL). The yield of lignin oil reached 85.68 % at 270 °C for 30 min. The catalytic performance was further improved by the introduction of CuO. Under the optimized conditions (290 °C, 120 min), the yield of lignin oil was up to 95.13 % using N-C (4:1) as the catalyst. The GC-MS analysis showed that the lignin oil mainly consisted of phenols, esters, hydrocarbons, and other oxygenated compounds, among which, the phenolic content was up to 57.90 %. These results indicate that the prepared catalyst can effectively break the C-O and C-C bonds in lignin and significantly promote the formation of phenolics.
